| primigenius indicus synonyms = Bos taurus, Bos indicus range_map = Bovine
| range-2013-14-02.png range_map_caption = Bovine range

}} 'Cattle' (colloquially 'cows') are the most common type of large domesticated
ungulates. They are a prominent modern member of the subfamily Bovinae, are the
most widespread species of the genus [[Bos]], and are most commonly classified
collectively as 'Bos primigenius'. Cattle are raised as livestock for meat (beef
and veal), as dairy animals for milk and other dairy products, and as draft
animals (oxen or bullocks) (pulling carts, plows and the like). Other products
include leather and dung for manure or fuel. In some countries, such as India,
cattle are sacred. From as few as 80 progenitors domesticated in southeast
Turkey about 10,500 years ago, Bollongino, Ruth & al.
Molecular Biology and Evolution.
"[http://mbe.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2012/03/14/molbev.mss092 Modern
Taurine Cattle descended from small number of Near-Eastern founders]". 7 Mar
2012. Accessed 2 Apr 2012. Op. cit. in Wilkins, Alasdair. io9.com. "[http://io9.com/5897169/dna-reveals-that-cows-were-almost-impossible-to-
domesticate?tag=archaeology DNA reveals that cows were almost impossible to
domesticate]". 28 Mar 2012. Accessed 2 Apr 2012. an estimated 1.3 billion
cattle are in the world today. [http://cattle-
today.com/ Breeds of Cattle at CATTLE TODAY ]
In 2009, cattle became the first livestock animal to have a fully mapped
genome.
